Title: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Image Guidance Systems in Neurosurgery

Background: Despite widespread adoption of image guidance systems in neurosurgery, evidence supporting their efficacy is limited. This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of various image guidance systems compared to standard surgery.

Methods: This preclinical randomised study involved 50 novice surgeons, randomly assigned to one of five groups: (1) no image guidance, (2) triplanar display, (3) always-on solid overlay, (4) always-on wire mesh overlay, and (5) on-demand inverse realism overlay. Participants were tasked with identifying a basilar tip aneurysm in a validated model head. Primary outcomes were time to task completion (seconds) and tool path length (millimeters), measured immediately post-intervention. Secondary outcomes included recognition of an unexpected finding and subjective depth perception. Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment ensured. Blinding was not applicable due to the study design.

Results: Image guidance significantly reduced time to task completion and tool path length compared to no guidance (p < 0.001 and p = 0.003, respectively). Augmented reality groups showed reduced tool path distance compared to triplanar display (p = 0.010). Always-on solid overlay led to the highest inattentional blindness (20% recognition of unexpected finding). Wire mesh and on-demand overlays reduced inattentional blindness, comparable to triplanar display (40% recognition). Wire mesh and inverse realism overlays improved subjective depth perception compared to always-on solid overlay (p = 0.031 and p = 0.008). No adverse events were reported.

Interpretation: Augmented reality platforms may improve performance in novice surgeons, though all modalities pose a risk of inattentional blindness. Trial registration: [Number]. Funding: [Source].
